questions.question: What is patent infringement?
options: Making, using, selling, or importing a patented invention without permission
questions.explanation: Patent infringement is making, using, selling, or importing a patented invention without the owner's permission.

questions.question: What is the test for patent infringement?
options: All-elements rule - product must contain every element of a claim
questions.explanation: The all-elements rule: a product infringes if it contains every single element listed in at least one claim.

questions.question: If a product is missing one element from a claim, does it infringe?
questions.explanation: No, if even one element is missing from the claim, there is no infringement.

questions.question: What is 'Freedom to Operate' (FTO)?
options: Analysis to see if your product infringes other people's patents
questions.explanation: FTO is an analysis to determine if your product is clear of all other active patents.

questions.question: Is a patent a positive or negative right?
options: Positive - right to make and sell
Negative - right to stop others, not right to make
questions.explanation: A patent is a negative right - it gives you the right to stop others, not the right to make or sell.

questions.question: Does having a patent automatically give you the right to sell your product?
options: No, you might still infringe someone else's broader patent
questions.explanation: No, your patented invention might still infringe someone else's older, broader patent.

questions.question: What is a 'blocking patent'?
options: A patent that blocks you from using your own patented invention
questions.explanation: A blocking patent is when someone else's patent blocks you from using your own patented invention.

questions.question: In the Smart Car case study, who had the broad patent?
options: Company A with the GPS self-driving patent from 2010
questions.explanation: Company A had the broad patent on 'a car that uses GPS to drive itself' from 2010.

questions.question: In the Smart Car case, what did your company invent?
options: A new laser sensor for self-driving cars
questions.explanation: Your company invented a new type of laser sensor for self-driving cars.

questions.question: In the Smart Car case, can you sell your car?
options: No, you infringe Company A's broader patent
questions.explanation: No, even though you have a patent on the laser, you still infringe Company A's broader GPS self-driving patent.

questions.question: In the Smart Car case, what happens if Company A uses your laser?
questions.explanation: If Company A uses your laser sensor, they infringe your patent.

questions.question: What is the solution to a blocking patent situation?
options: Cross-licensing - both give permission to each other
questions.explanation: Cross-licensing is the solution - both parties give each other permission to use their patents.

questions.question: How common are blocking patent situations?
questions.explanation: Blocking patent situations are very common, especially in technology industries.

questions.question: What does 'cross-licensing' mean?
options: Two parties give each other permission to use their patents
questions.explanation: Cross-licensing is when two parties give each other permission to use their respective patents.

questions.question: Can you infringe a patent even if you independently invented it?
options: No, independent invention is a defense
Yes, independent invention is not a defense in patent law
Only if you knew about it
questions.explanation: Yes, independent invention is not a defense - if you infringe the claims, you infringe regardless of how you invented it.

questions.question: What must you compare to determine infringement?
options: The product to the patent's claims
questions.explanation: You must compare the accused product directly to the patent's claims.

questions.question: If your product has all elements of Claim 1 plus extra features, does it infringe?
options: Yes, it contains all elements of the claim
questions.explanation: Yes, if it contains all elements of the claim, it infringes even if it has additional features.

questions.question: What is the purpose of an FTO analysis?
options: To ensure your product doesn't infringe others' patents before launch
questions.explanation: FTO analysis ensures your product is clear of other patents before you invest in manufacturing and launch.

questions.question: When should you do an FTO analysis?
options: Before investing heavily in a product
questions.explanation: You should do FTO analysis before investing heavily in manufacturing and launching a product.

questions.question: Can two companies both have patents that block each other?
options: Yes, this is a common blocking patent scenario
questions.explanation: Yes, it's common for two companies to have patents that block each other, requiring cross-licensing.

questions.question: What does a patent give you the right to do?
options: Exclude others from making, using, or selling the invention
questions.explanation: A patent gives you the right to exclude others, not necessarily the right to make or sell yourself.

questions.question: Why is understanding FTO important?
options: Your new patent doesn't guarantee you can sell your product
questions.explanation: It's crucial because having a patent doesn't guarantee you have freedom to operate - you might still infringe others.

questions.question: In the Smart Car case, who is blocking whom?
questions.explanation: Both companies block each other - you can't use their GPS patent, they can't use your laser patent.

questions.question: What is the 'all-elements rule'?
options: Must have every element of at least one claim to infringe
questions.explanation: The all-elements rule means a product must have every element of at least one claim to infringe.

questions.question: Can you design around a patent?
options: Yes, by removing or changing elements so you don't meet all claim elements
questions.explanation: Yes, you can design around a patent by removing or changing elements so you don't meet all the claim elements.
